reviewText:
I like this game, I've completed it twice. It's ♥♥♥♥ing weird, which is what I have come to expect from Ice-Pick Lodge, and why they're probably my favourite developer. They never play it safe, and they're always trying something new.

Cargo is totally strange, set around a rather shakey premise (stopping the rotation of the planet would NOT switch off" gravity... I'm just saying) involving harvesting Fun (the game's currency) from little naked dudes and conversing with these mechanical "gods" with grotesque circus masks...

The voice acting is dreadful (may just be a problem with the English version
date: the developers are based in Russia)

reviewText:
An entertaining, if confusing, game

Story Summary: Three bumbling Gods responsible for recreating Earth as an experiment hire a zeppelin captain and his pilot/mechanic Flawkes to deliver parts so they can repair their planet-building machine. The devil, who sabotaged the planet-building machine, talks Flawkes into editing the Earth into his own image. Flawkes must entertain the proto-humans (called Buddies) to produce FUN, a currency that can be used to build machines and pull heavy objects out of the stratosphere.

This game is a mix of puzzle-solving and building and driving around in your own crazy vehicles. The faster/higher they go, the more entertained the Buddies will become and the more FUN you earn.

Playtime: about 6 hours to complete the story mode

Pros:
* The story and visuals are hilarious at times: the first time I had a “Buddy dance party”, I was laughing so hard I couldn’t breathe.
* Vehicle building is easy and fun, designs can be saved and reloaded at will. Or, if you don't enjoy it, you can use pre-made blueprints and skip vehicle building altogether.
* Game lets you import and use your own music for Buddy dances.

Cons:
* Crashes, bugs, and insufficient auto-saves. Twice I managed to strand a submarine underneath the seafloor, once while going past a loading screen and another while editing the submarine when it was resting on the sea floor. The game only autosaves at the beginning of a new season, and seasons are very long. I’ve also read reports of the game failing to load saves made at particular times.

*** Important: if you decide to play this, save your game often and save in a new slot each time. ***

* Sometimes it’s hard to know what the game expects you to do. I had to consult a walkthrough for the volcano restarting section in winter, and for the tornado sequence in summer. I also had to look up online what the key for placing clefs was. (Enter.) This might be due to poorly-done translation of the guiding text (Cargo was originally developed in Russian.)
* Airplanes don’t control well.

If you’re a fan of games with weird characters and settings, like Zeno Clash, a fan of games where you build vehicles, like Spore or Kerbal Space Program, or a fan of silly nonsense humor, I think you'll enjoy this game.

reviewText: This is what would happen if The Residents and The Polyphonic Spree made a game together. Actually, if they did make this game, the result would be a bit more coherent and a lot less bewildering than this! I appreciate what the game is trying to do - blend surreality and a little of everything into their game, then marry it to their vehicle building gameplay mechanic. You build vehicles! You're not really sure why you're building them or why the hell you're doing this, but the main thing to know is this: You can kick little naked midgets off of the sides of mountains for points. Plus you can put music in the game and have the little naked midgets dance to this. The high point of this game is getting the little naked midgets to dance to The Residents' Commercial Album. So get that if you're going to get this.

reviewText: A rough gem with some control issues and wonky physics, but so worth the effort, in my opinion. This is one of the most bizarre games I have ever played. I am not even sure wat genre should I classify it into. I will just describe what you do in this game: you run around, collect vehicle parts, build vehicles out of them, drop stuff from orbit, reignite volcanoes, drive, sail, dive, fly, kick small, bald, children-like buddies who explode with flowers and confetti, and most of all you get FUN, loads and loads of FUN.\n\nThe game is very family friendly - there is almost no violence, except for aforementioned kicking and some driving over penguins (they are evil penguins, though).

reviewText: I bought this during the (2011?) Holiday Sale because it looked like quirky fun...and (ok) because I wanted the achievement for the steam badge or coal or whatever it was.  I enjoyed playing it briefly then, though I seem to recall the vehicle construction feeling a bit clunky and frustrating.  I got whatever the achievement was, and played for another hour or so, and then dropped it until tonight.  Picked up from my savegame, and after the initial confusion of wondering wtf was going on and what music notes did, got back into it.\n\nIt's definitely different, and quirky, and humorous.  The vehicle creation can be a bit frustrating, particularly until you get used to it a bit (dragging vs clicking, making sure you click on joints so you don't reset the piece type, etc.), but the only real remaining frustration I had there was when I couldn't delete a piece because it had attachments (I think it was based on the order you placed the pieces, so that even if there was a valid connection" elsewhere
date: it wouldn't let you delete the initial "connection"
recommended: resulting in having to remove and recreate a whole bunch of pieces).   If you are expecting something serious
voteText: or particularly challenging I doubt very much you'll enjoy this.  Revel in the silliness
votesHelpful: and ♥♥♥♥ around plently and you're likely to have a good time.  I'll probably revisit it at some point in the future to make silly vehicles

reviewText: This game felt like it had potential, up until the point where it utterly sucked. Which was the first 2 minutes of the game. You crash land on an island filled with masked gods (Which have the longest, most annoying, and out of context conversations) and small man babies that you can kick around the island for some kind of point system. The objective of the game is to rechieve enough pieces from your blimp to rebuild it and fly off the god for sacken island. From what the trailer and images showed is that it is a sandbox adventure game in which you can create various aircrafts and boats to do various tasks with. But from the gameplay it shows that you have to pay in game currency for parts of the ships and it took me the two hours of playing this game to figure out how to activate the building sequence. Horrific voice acting, terrible and slow gameplay, and aweful game mechanics. Not even worth the two dollars I paid for this piece of crap on a Steam sale. -100000000/10

reviewText:
This game is one you can't take seriously. If you take games seriously then this game won't be fun for you.

That being said, the voice acting is awful save for the 'gods' in the game. Even then it's a little bit... Eh. But the game itself is fun. The physics in the game can be a little bit frustrating along with the objectives as the hints they give are vague at best. The building is fun, and the game got more than a good giggle out of me. It's silly and off the wall.

I wouldn't recommend paying 9.99 for it. Get it on sale, preferrably 3-4 dollars. It's definitely worth a couple of bucks for the good laughs if you like random comedy that doesn't entirely make sense.

reviewText: Cargo is by Icepick Lodge, the same people who made the bleak, weird artsy games Pathologic and The Void.  It keeps the weirdness but the game is really silly.  You run around kicking naked baby men called Buddies as Fawkes, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off mechanic.  You also design custom cars, ships, and airplanes from parts you find laying around or you buy from god (who is comprised of 3 masks).  It's not too difficult to make things, but you can't get too elaborate because if you leave the Buddies alone too long they start jumping into fan blades and such.  There's some puzzles to solve but 90% of the game is keeping the little ♥♥♥♥ers alive so you can kick them to generate fun.  If they have enough fun, they explode, but that doesn't count as dying????  Keeping enough buddies alive for the good ending is frustrating due to some physics glitches that pop up, but overall it's a pretty fun game.

reviewText:
A very very unorthodox type of game but very fun.

In this game you basically build a vehicle with premade parts to accomplish a objective. The mechanics are well implemented with the exception some elements not being extremely well polished such as the flying or underwater vehicle controls. I found going to deep or to high very easy to do at times on mistake. The game just really works and is fun. Its not extremely well polished but thats almost negligible because the gameplay is solid.

Its an adventure game in a time when good adventure games are dead.

Cargo reminds me of Banjoo Kazooi Nuts and Bolts or Garrys Mod (but unlike Gmod theres specific goals and a point to keep playing the game aside from messing around) The major downsides is in its polishing. This is a low budget game from Russia is what it feels like to me, and it is definetly from Russia.

Sometimes a puzzle can be confusing as to how to actually solve it but usually just keeping doing what I was doing worked out. That said the puzzles usually arn't terribly repatitive but I didn't enjoy the sub level because I was very unsure of what to do at that point and I was forced to back track for awhile.

But the setting is very whacky, characters goofy and entertaining, and the game itself is fun. Just building a vehicle once you figure it all out can be fun, while the game isn't terribly long and dousn't drag on fortunately.

Its a good game if you can let go of the negative aspects and have fun with the gameplay and whacky story.

This game is cuh-razy and pretty cool but its not very high quality unfortunately. But how much can you expect from a Russian game made in an apartment or something like that? Just try to get it cheap, $5 or around there is a decent price.

reviewText: I'll be honest with you guys. I've got this game for free and thought I should give it a try. Now, I don't like to badmouth other people's work, but if you're looking for a good time, this game ain't what you want. I couldn't understand what I'm doing and where I'm doing it. The story must've been written on an acid trip, in my honest opinion. Now, this was a few years ago when I gave the game a try but it looked like something from the early 2000's (maybe Quake 2 had this kind of graphics, the fine detail are thankfully a bit hazy).\nSo, to sum it up, if the developers wanted to confuse gamers, they did a good job. This game is hella confusing, like when you meet a drunkard on the street who insists that 'They' have stolen his pet shrimp.

reviewText:
This must be one of the first game from Ice pick lodge that doesn't cause you any much of those stress" and also assorting with vivid color to a point of madness............:) But all of that come with much cost in consideration of their very reputation also. Which I conclude to this..

Pro
+ Artistic look in both design and color palette
+ Quirky and Goofy in every aspect
+ Quite brilliant in the scope of "Lego"
+ You can add your own song too!! (Even for 60 second segment though) for a better "Buddy" Dance music.

Con
- Voice acting was sooooo..... I have no word for it. It is just very intentionally bad from my point of view
- Audio mash up
date: Every soundtrack in this game seem really try their best to see "Who play the loudest noise"\n- Story was obscured and very very very hard to comprehend
recommended: Even after finishing the game\n\nIn the end I hape to not recommended this game..... I know I know. I feel sad about it. But this game was really somehow for a "specific" kind of group and not everyone would hated it but still neither to love it. Maybe you could try it just for fun when its on the discount though."

reviewText: The game looks like it's about solving puzzles with Kerbal Space Program-esque building. The building is limited, the physics is wonky, the setting is weird, the audio sounds like the developers made funny noises into a microphone, and the actual gameplay is grindy and repetative. The game constantly bombards you with large messages splashed across the screen like 'Having Fun Yet?' or 'The End Is Near'. No, game, I wasn't having fun, and yes, I really hope the end is near so I can go do something else. Would not recommend

reviewText:
I just dont even know... I think the devs were on some harsh drugs developing this game. The humor isnt funny, the story is crap, the art direction is crap, the collision is crap, the voice acting is crap, the gameplay is crap, the crafting system is crap... Do you get where this is going yet?

The game is full of bugs and lacking in features. The jumping mechanic is awkward to say the least. I cant really think of anything good to say about the game.

Where is the depth to the crafting? Where is a quality control for the volume for the voice actors? It sounds like the captain was recorded in a different studio. Why is Fun" forced down your damn throat? Hint to the devs ---> if you have to ask if your customers are having fun
date: THEY ARENT <---- Why are the cut scenes unskipable. Why does it matter to save 1 or 2 buddies when its so easy to get more? Why can you not explore the buildings and such you bring down from the stratosphere? Where is the multiplayer? Why are the buddies so god damn anoying? Who was in charge of the sounds? Who thought the mechanics for the submarine was a good idea? Who thought the lame ♥♥♥ "Organ hero" mini game was fun? Who though the life saver link on the vehicles was a good idea to be such a big part of the game? Why does your character just say "I love my job" over and over?\n\nWhere is the inspiration? This is little more than a group of teenages sitting around a table smoking a bowl coming up with a game."

reviewText:
This game doesn't  make any sense to me. Ok, you build vehicles, but around naked midgets who shoot rainbows and stars when killed or kicked. What ?! That's right, NAKED MIDGETS. And not the female kind (which wouldn't be any better, really), but the bold, male midget kind. And they play, among other things, in some sort of big band, with a vocalist that rhymes. I can hear you say 'you lost me when you said naked midgets, man'. In that case I salute you. And you may join the club.
So, if the things I just said make any sense to you... --> There's the Buy button.
To all the others; avoid, unless you can get it really, really cheap.

[Rating: 67/100]

I tried playing the demo when it first came out. It crashed before I'd saved, 15 minutes in, and I didn't feel like slogging through the introduction again.

A couple of years later, got it in a bundle and gave it another go. It crashed before I'd saved 15 minutes in and I really didn't feel like slogging through the introduction again.

It thinks it's much funnier than it really is, and it just doesn't feel worth fighting technical issues for.

reviewText: At first this game might seem a bit weird but give it a little time.  Soon you'll be building your own boats, cars, planes, and helicopters. It's definitely not what people would usually expect from a game but I'd consider it worth it. Not everybody is going to like this game but if you do then you'll probably love it.

reviewText: Fresh out of college, your character finds the prospect of working with honey uninspiring. She flies outside the hive for the first time and talks to a human (Renée Zellweger), breaking a cardinal rule of her species. The character learns that humans have been stealing and eating honey for centuries, and she realizes that her true calling is to obtain justice for her kind by suing humanity for theft.
